meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 入 means "enter," but this word does not mean "to enter" (which you already learned as 入る). Still, the meaning of 入れる is still related to the kanji's meaning: it means <vocabulary>to insert</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary>. It's something you do to another object, like inserting a key into a lock, or your hand into a glove.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>above</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to go up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>.

It's an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. For example: Prices go up. Temperatures rise. See? No direct object. You can remember this because stock prices always seems to go up when you see this one <reading>girl</reading> (がる). You don't know how this girl makes stock prices go up, she just does. Think of her as your lucky girl.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>below</kanji>, and 下がる means <vocabulary>to get lower</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary>.

It's an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. For example: Prices fall. Temperatures come down. See? No direct object. You can remember this because your fever only goes down when a <reading>girl</reading> (がる) takes care of you. It has to be a girl if you want your fever to come down!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 出る means "to <kanji>exit</kanji>," and this is the transitive version of that. In other words, you're doing the action of causing something else to exit, so this word means <vocabulary>to take out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hand out</vocabulary>. Think of it like this: when you take out your wallet, you're causing it to exit your pocket.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life" so what is the verb form of that? Would it be "to do life"? No, probably not. In this case it is <vocabulary>to give birth</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to produce</vocabulary>.

You'll have to differentiate this one from the word 生まれる as well. Just remember that when you give birth, you're the one who has to actually <reading>mo</reading>ve (む) your body by finding the right position and pushing with every ounce of strength you can muster. In contrast, when you're being born, you can just kind of lie there and enjoy the ride.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" and this means <vocabulary>to stand something up</vocabulary>. It also can mean <vocabulary>to make something</vocabulary>, both in a physical sense, like making a sound, and a mental sense, like making a plan. 

Don't confuse this with 立つ. 立てる means that you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will erect the flag." You're doing the action to something else.

This word means <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary>, which might surprise you if you remember that the kanji 分 means <kanji>part</kanji>. Think of it this way: to understand something you have to break it down into its parts to see how it works.

Watch out, though, because whereas in English you understand something, in Japanese the thing you understand is the grammatical subject (it's doing the action). So, a more literal meaning for this is <vocabulary>to be understandable</vocabulary>. In other words, there's no object, and 分かる is intransitive, meaning it happens on its own. The かる ending is a hint, because verbs with かる as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>stop</kanji>, so the verb 止まる means <vocabulary>to stop</vocabulary>. 

But this is the intransitive version, so it doesn't take a direct object. A train stops, or you stop at a red light. See? No direct object. You can remember this because you often have to stop when you see a 丸 (まる), a.k.a. a circle. Think about it — red lights, the cancel symbol, and no trespassing signs are all 丸. Even stop signs are… sort of 丸?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's.
What do you think a <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> is? If I were to guess, I'd say a <vocabulary>bold letter</vocabulary>. You know, like <vocabulary>bold text</vocabulary> on a screen.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>see</kanji>, and 見える is <vocabulary>to be visible</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in sight</vocabulary>, though it's often more naturally translated into English as <vocabulary>can see</vocabulary>. It's used when you don't actively intend to see something, it just happens.

This verb can also mean <vocabulary>to seem</vocabulary>, when talking about how you perceive something you can see.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

皮 refers to <vocabulary>skin</vocabulary> as something separate from the body. You can use 皮 for when your skin starts to peel off with sunburn, or for animal skin when it is being stripped off or turned into a <vocabulary>hide</vocabulary>. You can also use 皮 to describe the outer layer of fruits and vegetables, like apple skins or banana <vocabulary>peel</vocabulary>s.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to mix something</vocabulary>. 

It’s transitive, so you’re doing the mixing. With this word, the things you’ve mixed are still distinguishable from each other. Two types of fish in your aquarium, books of different genres on your shelf — that kind of thing.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>meet</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to encounter</vocabulary>.

Just like its kanji, this word also means <vocabulary>light</vocabulary>. In some cases, it can also refer to a <vocabulary>flash</vocabulary> of light.

This is the more general word for light compared to 明かり, which is why it's often used for sunlight as well.
The <kanji>moon</kanji> <kanji>light</kanji> is exactly what it sounds like: it's <vocabulary>moonlight</vocabulary>! This word can also refer to a <vocabulary>moonbeam</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>light</kanji>. What kind of light would this be? Obviously <vocabulary>sunlight</vocabulary>.

This word is the kanji <kanji>same</kanji> with hiragana attached, and it also means <vocabulary>same</vocabulary>.

It's a bit of an oddball among Japanese adjectives, because you don't need な or い to attach it to a noun. So it's usually considered to be a "special" な-adjective. Have a look at the context sentences to see it in action!

You have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>, which comes out to <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is quite formal. To say <vocabulary>the same day</vocabulary> more casually, just use 同じ日 (おなじひ)!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>times</kanji>. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to go around</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rotate</vocabulary>.

Bear in mind that this verb is intransitive, so it happens on its own. Something revolves or rotates, all by itself.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>one time</vocabulary>. How many times? Just one.
The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>this time</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is really just <vocabulary>every time</vocabulary>. Do you get your kanji readings correct 毎回?

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>many</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>many</vocabulary> (or you could say <vocabulary>much</vocabulary>). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright?

You have <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? <vocabulary>Maybe</vocabulary>. How about this one? Hmm, <vocabulary>maybe</vocabulary> that one too.

You know this is a verb because it ends with an う sound. The kanji for this word is <kanji>right</kanji> or <kanji>success</kanji>, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. But it's mostly for when things go right. As in <vocabulary>to be right</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on target</vocabulary>. 

当たる is intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. Your answer is right, or your shot is on target. See? No direct object.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>right</kanji>. What happens when you get "a right?" You get <vocabulary>a success</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>moon</kanji> is <vocabulary>every month</vocabulary> (as you know from all the month-related vocab). This can also mean <vocabulary>monthly</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is <vocabulary>daily</vocabulary> (or just <vocabulary>every day</vocabulary>).
You have <kanji>every</kanji> and <kanji>year</kanji> to combine into <vocabulary>every year</vocabulary> (<vocabulary>yearly</vocabulary> works as well).

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

Note that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ごはん. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>think</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to think about</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to consider</vocabulary>. 

Note that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is 思う.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
What do you call <kanji>cow</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji>? You call it <vocabulary>beef</vocabulary> (what's for dinner?).

The <kanji>skin</kanji> on the <kanji>meat</kanji> is kind of like the outer shell. It's not very nice, and people who eat only meat skin tend to use <vocabulary>sarcasm</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>irony</vocabulary>. That being said, Japanese people don't really understand sarcasm. So, maybe that's why "meat skin" means "sarcasm." Is this ironic? Now I'm not even sure.

One’s <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji> is, after everything, still <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary>. And the part that’s from my self is, well, <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary>. Everyone has their own part of their self. Pretty straightforward.

By your<kanji>self</kanji>, you managed to <kanji>stand</kanji>. Nobody helped you. You stood up on your own, and you really showed your <vocabulary>independence</vocabulary> in the process!

自立 primarily refers to a person's <vocabulary>self-reliance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>autonomy</vocabulary> — their ability to stand on their own, make decisions, and act independently (as opposed to the political independence of a country or something).
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is the kanji <kanji>color</kanji> repeated twice (the 々 character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means <vocabulary>various</vocabulary>.

You'd think that <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is <vocabulary>sky blue</vocabulary> in English. <vocabulary>Light blue</vocabulary> works as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go</kanji> so the verb form of this is <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary>.

This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means <kanji>go</kanji>. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the き to help you to remember that this word means <vocabulary>train direction</vocabulary> (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (き) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "<vocabulary>bound for</vocabulary>" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>thousand</kanji>? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "<vocabulary>thousands</vocabulary>."

If this is used in a question, it can also mean <vocabulary>how many thousands</vocabulary>?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When you ask <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>people</kanji> you're not actually asking "what people?" You're asking <vocabulary>how many people</vocabulary>. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you.
You have <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> - as in: <vocabulary>what month</vocabulary> is it? It's １０月, you fool. Get a job, hippy.
<kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> equals the fairly obvious translation "<vocabulary>what day</vocabulary>." But, it also means <vocabulary>how many days</vocabulary>.

You have the kanji <kanji>what</kanji> and <kanji>year</kanji>, as in: "<vocabulary>what year</vocabulary> is it?" 

This also means <vocabulary>how many years</vocabulary> too, depending on the context. As in: "<vocabulary>How many years</vocabulary> did you play soccer?"

<kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji>? This doesn't make any sense. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. So, for this one it's <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>study</kanji> or <kanji>learning</kanji>. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary>. 

There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is 習う. You'll learn this one later on. 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う, so keep that in mind when you use it.
Who has a <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>? Only one person that I know of, and that's a <vocabulary>student</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your <vocabulary>school grade</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>enter</kanji> into a <kanji>study</kanji> (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka <vocabulary>school admission</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>university admission</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>entry into school</vocabulary>.
Someone with the <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>industry</kanji> is someone who creates things. That would be the study of <vocabulary>engineering</vocabulary>.
What's the <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>study</kanji>? If I had to choose, I'd probably say this is <vocabulary>college</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>university</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>rest</kanji> from <kanji>school</kanji> you are taking an <vocabulary>absence from school</vocabulary>. This is only for very long absences though, not a day or a week, but months or years. Think about it like taking an extended leave of absence from school.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>... once known as a mystical essence that kept us from flying into space. Now we know this is the <vocabulary>air</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>, though, because that's what a bunch of air between the earth and space is called. ここの空気はいいね！

Figuratively, this can also refer to the <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary> that's in the air or room, but not a specific person's mood!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You have some <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji>s. What balls are more important than any other balls, at least for a dude? That would be his <vocabulary>testicles</vocabulary>. 

This word came about because tanuki scrotum skin would be used to pound down gold into sheets. Tanuki scrotums are apparently very good at this because they are very strong and very flexible. Strange, yeah? That's why Gold balls = testicles.

As you might have guessed, this word is slang and you'll probably want to avoid using it at the doctor's! It's a comical word that is used in casual situations.

The お is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was <vocabulary>money</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>blue</kanji>? It's still <vocabulary>blue</vocabulary>! It can also mean <vocabulary>unripe</vocabulary>, which might sound confusing, but it comes down to the fact that in Japanese there's some overlap between blue and green. So while in English we think of the "go" traffic light and unripe bananas as "green," in Japanese they're actually called "blue."

Someone who is in their <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>young man</vocabulary>. 

青年 refers to <vocabulary>young adult</vocabulary>s, usually in their late teens to early twenties. The word is gender-neutral in legal or official contexts, but in everyday use 青年 usually refers to young men.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>make</kanji>. The verb form of that is <vocabulary>to make</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You have your <kanji>body</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji>. This is just another way to say <vocabulary>physical strength</vocabulary>. Watch out, if you use too much of your physical strength you may run out of physical <vocabulary>stamina</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary> completely! They're tied together, so make sure to pace yourself.

The <kanji>body</kanji>'s <kanji>inside</kanji> means <vocabulary>inside the body</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>internal</vocabulary>.

体内 refers specifically to internal body stuff, so you'll often see it in medical and scientific contexts.

When you <kanji>make</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji>, what are you doing? Simply put, you're <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>. If you want to be fancier about it, you could say this is <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>.

Note that 作文 often refers to the end result of a writing process, like a finished essay, rather than the writing process itself. It’s also commonly associated with various writing tasks assigned to students in Japanese elementary or middle school.

What is the "<kanji>industry</kanji> of <kanji>make</kanji>"? Well, it's when you industriously make things, obviously. That can only be <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crafts</vocabulary>, often referring to craft activities or hands-on projects done in elementary or middle school!

But wait, 工作 isn't just about glue and popsicle sticks! It can also mean <vocabulary>maneuvering</vocabulary>, in the sense of pulling strings behind the scenes. So, whether you're crafting a masterpiece or scheming a clever plan, 工作 encompasses the wonders of crafting!

The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>make</kanji>! What is your big make? Bigger than anything else. It is your <vocabulary>major work</vocabulary>!

大作 means a large-scale, ambitious, or significant work. Depending on the context, it can refer to anything from an artistically accomplished <vocabulary>masterpiece</vocabulary> to a big-budget <vocabulary>blockbuster</vocabulary> movie.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a <vocabulary>loud voice</vocabulary>!

大声 usually just describes talking in a <vocabulary>big voice</vocabulary>, but it can also refer to shouting depending on the situation.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have an <kanji>older brother</kanji> and a <kanji>younger brother</kanji>. Wow! Both are here. These are <vocabulary>brothers</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>come</kanji> so you know this word means <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is the <vocabulary>next month</vocabulary>! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one!
The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is <vocabulary>next year</vocabulary>! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one!

Things that are really <kanji>old</kanji> <kanji>come</kanji> <vocabulary>from ancient times</vocabulary>!

This is a relatively formal expression that’s used to talk about <vocabulary>age-old</vocabulary> things, like customs that have stood the test of time.

When you have <kanji>year</kanji>s <kanji>com</kanji>ing and going, you know it is <vocabulary>for some years</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this one with 来年 which means "next year." The kanji 来 comes after the kanji for year, so instead of "coming year" it's "years that come (and go)." At least, you can think of it that way to differentiate. 

You can also add numbers to this word. For example ５年来 means something to the tune of "for five years." But this is a pretty formal word. Just keep that in mind.

When you're doing something <kanji>inside</kanji> the <kanji>company</kanji> you're doing it <vocabulary>within the company</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in-house</vocabulary>. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor.
When you <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>company</kanji> you're actually <vocabulary>joining a company</vocabulary>. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed!
The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is where everything in your company comes from. This is your main base. This is your <vocabulary>headquarters</vocabulary>.
The place where your <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>company</vocabulary>. Sony is a company. Nintendo is a company. Etc.

When the kanji for <kanji>angle</kanji> is used as a standalone word, it usually means <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary>. You can remember this because corners are pretty much the most common kind of angle you see in everyday life.

In math contexts, it can also mean <vocabulary>angle</vocabulary> — just like the kanji's meaning!
When you have something with <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>angle</kanji>s, what shape is that? It's a <vocabulary>triangle</vocabulary>.

What shape has <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>angle</kanji>s? The most common one is a <vocabulary>square</vocabulary>, but it could also be a <vocabulary>rectangle</vocabulary> or even a <vocabulary>cube</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>say</kanji>, so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>run</kanji> so now you know the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to run</vocabulary>.

A vehicle that <kanji>run</kanji>-<kanji>go</kanji>es is <vocabulary>running</vocabulary> and it's <vocabulary>moving</vocabulary> you somewhere else. You're <vocabulary>traveling</vocabulary>!

This word is typically used to describe the movement of vehicles such as cars and trains. It carries a slightly formal or rigid tone, so keep an eye on our context sentences to make sure you’re using it right!

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>near</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>close</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a day coming very <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>. It's a day coming <vocabulary>in a few days</vocabulary> or in the <vocabulary>coming days</vocabulary>. In other words, you wouldn't use this word for something that's going to happen in a few minutes, or a few months.

This is a relatively formal word that is commonly used in professional or official contexts.

The <kanji>close</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s are years that aren't too long ago. They are the <vocabulary>recent years</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word that is often used in writing or formal speech.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>man</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>boy</vocabulary>.

There's a の particle stuck in the middle of this word. Here it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after. 

But for now, all you really have to remember is that 男の子 means "boy."

When you think of a <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji> what do you think of? My mind immediately goes to a <vocabulary>caterpillar</vocabulary>. Imagine the furriest caterpillar you can and touch it. How does it feel? Furry?

You have the <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>town</kanji>. Does this sort of sound familiar? We have another word for it in English, but it's essentially the same thing: <vocabulary>downtown</vocabulary>. It isn't the downtown you might be used to though. In Japan, this is an old word that was used for the commercial districts literally, physically down (lower than) the main city. So picture an old, urban Japanese area!

A <kanji>man</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>man</vocabulary>. 

There's a の particle stuck in the middle of this word. Here it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after. 

Don't worry if that's hard to remember though. Just remember 男の人 means "man" (and that it's more polite than plain 男).
You know that 今 means now. What you probably don't know is that まで means "until." So, this word means <vocabulary>until now</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>string</kanji> (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully <vocabulary>wool yarn</vocabulary>.

You'll have to learn this word in two parts. You already know the meaning of 今 because of the kanji, which means "now." The すぐ part, however, is a new word, meaning "soon." すぐ and "soon" even start with a similar sound, so maybe that can help you remember this! If you put 今 and すぐ together, you get "now soon." Put in better English, that's <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>right now</vocabulary>.

This is the village you came from. This is where your parents live. This is your <vocabulary>hometown</vocabulary> (same meaning as the kanji you learned).

This word is old-fashioned and evokes a warm, nostalgic image of home. Often seen in folktales and traditional songs, it represents an idyllic, pastoral life.

You have your <kanji>home village</kanji> and your <kanji>heart</kanji>. Your heart always resides in your home village, so when you leave you feel <vocabulary>homesick</vocabulary>.

Young people don't really use this word anymore. It's more for the oldies. If you're an oldie, go right ahead. If you're a youngie, then talk to more oldies!

What is <kanji>real</kanji> is <kanji>right</kanji>. It is the <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. It is also the <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary>. Don't believe anything that isn't <vocabulary>real</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>true</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You learned 空 means "sky," but it can also mean "empty." An <kanji>empty</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> literally means "empty car," but in practice, you'll usually see this lit up on a taxi to mean <vocabulary>open taxi</vocabulary>. If you spot it, feel free to hail it down!

You might also see 空車 at a parking lot. In that case, it means there's an <vocabulary>empty parking space</vocabulary> available.

If you often <kanji>think</kanji> about <kanji>study</kanji>ing <kanji>old</kanji> things, it's called <vocabulary>archeology</vocabulary>. All archeology involves thinking about old things, at least a little bit.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji> is all you get. It's your <vocabulary>whole life</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>all through life</vocabulary>, and when it's used as an adjective it means <vocabulary>lifelong</vocabulary>.

Things you end up <kanji>doing</kanji> in the <kanji>grass</kanji> and not inside probably take a lot of big <vocabulary>gesture</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>s. You have to do them outside on the grass because if you did them anywhere else you might break something.
The kanji and the word share one of the same meanings: <vocabulary>form</vocabulary>. It doesn't just mean form though, it means <vocabulary>tense</vocabulary> too. Like verb tense.

You want to <kanji>mix</kanji> opinions from <kanji>outside</kanji> your country into the way you handle things. That's called <vocabulary>diplomacy</vocabulary>. If you mix your country with the ones outside of your own, you'll all profit!
Remember how you learned that 生まれる means "to be born?" Well once you're born that place where it happened becomes your <vocabulary>birthplace</vocabulary>!

If all you can see is the <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> of something, then you'll only get a <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> idea of what it is. You'll be able to say that it's <vocabulary>generally</vocabulary> a certain way, but that's <vocabulary>about</vocabulary> all. You'll get the <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary>, but no more.
If you <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji>, it's called <vocabulary>literature</vocabulary>. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you!
You want to talk about the <kanji>origin</kanji> where something <kanji>come</kanji>s from. That's where it is from <vocabulary>originally</vocabulary>.
This has the 〜 for counters, so you can bet this shares the <vocabulary>bread loaf counter</vocabulary> meaning with the kanji.

その means "that" or "the", and その plus <kanji>other</kanji> means things like <vocabulary>the others</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>other</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>other than that</vocabulary>, depending on the context.

Remember 北口 from a couple levels ago, and how 入り口 means "entrance" and 出口 means "exit?" Combine that 口 meaning with the kanji for <kanji>west</kanji>, and you get <vocabulary>west exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>west entrance</vocabulary>.

What's a "third day moon"? It's a <vocabulary>crescent moon</vocabulary>. A crescent moon is the newly visible moon that appears on the third day of the month in the lunar calendar that Japanese people used back in the day.
Remember how 上手 means that you're <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary> something? Well, this word uses the exact same kanji, and means the exact same thing!
You have the number "thirty", and <kanji>age</kanji>. So this refers to <vocabulary>one's thirties</vocabulary>.

When you buy something, you basically <kanji>substitute</kanji> it with <kanji>money</kanji>. That substitute money is the <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> of the thing you're paying for.

There are a lot of money-related synonyms in Japanese, but keep in mind this one refers to the money you pay to get some stuff in return (usually goods), not to an expense, price, or value. It's "substitute money" after all!
